results.title: Marie Antoinette, Reine de France = Marie Antoinette, Queen of France
results.brief_description:
Cast of 1000s extravaganza recounting the last days of the French monarchy and Queen Marie Antoinette’s affair with dashing Swedish ambassador, Axel Fersen.

Credits: Director, Jean Delannoy ; writers, Bernard Zimmer, Jean Delannoy, Philippe Erlanger ; photography, Pierre Montazel ; music, Jacques Simonot.
Cast: Michele Morgan, Richard Todd, Jacques Morel.

results.title: Les Enfants du Palais = Children of Justice
results.brief_description:
Judge Castaing in is charge of the Juvenile Delinquency Section of the Pantin area. Everyday he is faced with lost teenagers on the brink of criminality, irresponsible parents and an indifferent administration. Castaing is the archetypal ‘honest man’ who truly believes in his mission. Part judge, part father figure, the film shows a day in the life of a man who feels a father-like responsibility for every youth he is in charge of. All performances in ‘Les enfants du Palais’ ring so true that ultimately the spectator is compelled to share in Castaing’s anger and despair when one of his young charges is caught in a Police shoot-out. Filmed in documentary style (it is at times difficult to differentiate the actors from the real life participants), ‘Les enfants du Palais’ present a portrait of a system that has barely changed since the days of the infamous reformatories, and which is still unable to achieve its real mission: to save the children. See also: Les coeurs verts [X000390].

Credits: Director, Jean-Marie Perier ; music, Donovan.
Cast: Francois Perier, Martial Pautrel, Dani Graule, Simone Signoret (voice only).

results.title: Fidelio
results.creator_credit: Pierre Jourdan, Daniele Gegauff and Stephane Tchalgadjieff
results.brief_description:
This performance of ‘Fidelio’, Beethoven’s only opera was recorded at the antique theatre of Orange (France). The ‘Philharmonic Orchestra of Israel’ is conducted by Zubin Mehta, with the ‘New Philharmonia’ choir of London. The stage direction is by Alfred Lipmann. The performance is introduced by an extract from ‘Napoleon et la Revolution’ directed by Abel Gance. ‘Fidelio’ was composed in reaction to the shattered hopes of the French Revolution and Napoleon’s encroaching grip over Europe. It is a classic love story in which liberty and justice triumph of oppression and tyranny thanks to the steely resolve of love.

Credits: Producers, Daniele Gegauff, Stephane Tchalgadjieff ; director, Pierre Jourdain ; photography, Michel Kelber.
Cast: Gundula Janovitz, Jon Vickers, Theo Adam.

results.title: Joe Petit Boum-Boum
results.brief_description:
Joe has saved the royal beehive from being vandalised by a gang of nasty children. As a reward, the Queen invites Joe to visit her royal palace. Reduced to insect size, Joe embarks on the exploration of the bees’ tiny kingdom.

Credits: Director, Jean Image ; writers, Jean Image, France Image ; photograhy, T. Tchikine ; music, Michel Emer.
Cast: Laurence Badie, Roger Carel, Chritiane Legrand, Linette Lemercier [voices only].

results.title: Berenice
results.brief_description:
Berenice (1670) marks a decisive point in Racine’s theatrical career, for with this play he found a felicitous combination of elements that he would use, without radical alteration, for the rest of his secular tragedies: a love interest, a relatively uncomplicated plot, striking rhetorical passages, and a highly poetic use of time. Berenice is built around the unusual premise of three characters who are ultimately forced to live apart because of their virtuous sense of duty. In the play, Titus, who is to become the new Roman emperor, and his friend Antiochus are both in love with Berenice, the queen of Palestine. The play’s “majestic sadness,” as Racine put it in his preface to the play, flows from the tragic necessity of separation for individuals who yearn for union with their beloved and who express their sorrow in some of the most haunting passages of Racine’s entire oeuvre. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica. Online. http://www.eb.com

Credits: Director, Jean Kerchbron ; photography, Jacques Lemare.
Cast: Rene Arrieu, Jacques destoop, Sylvia Monfort, Marcelle Ransom, Jacques Dacqmines, William Sabatier.

results.title: La Carriere de Suzanne = Suzanne's Career
results.brief_description:
This early installment of the ‘Six Moral Tales ‘series revolves around the rather free-floating amourous life of a young student in the Latin Quarter in the 1960s. ‘La Carriere de Suzanne’ is not typical of the other ‘Contes Moraux’ involving four young people in game playing during the course of failed relationships. In this film the theme is both more complex and less clear than in the first moral tale.

Credits: Producer, Barbet Schroeder ; director, writer, editor, Eric Rohmer ; photography, Daniel Lacambre.
Cast: Catherine See, Philippe Beuzen, Christian Charriere.

results.title: Remparts D'argile = Ramparts of Clay
results.brief_description:
Rima, a young orphan, lives in an Algerian village whose chief source of income is a salt mine. When the absentee owner refuses to raise the wages of the labourers, a strike is called. The mine owner calls the army to the rescue. Rima resorts to a stratagem to get rid of the troups. ‘Remparts d’argile’ was filmed in semi-documentary fashion in the Algerian village of Tehouda with a cast of local residents. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1971.

Credits: Director, writers, Jean-Louis Bertucelli, Jean Duvignaud ; photography, Andreas Winding.
Cast: Leila Shanna.

results.title: Le Rayon Vert = the Green Ray
results.brief_description:
The central thematic of the Comedies and Proverbs series is the lack of any dominant moral direction among today’s young. The result inevitably is an immersion in self. Here a Parisian secretary, abandoned by her friends, cannot bear to spend an August in Paris. Her hopes of finding a dream lover are anything but fulfilled as she holidays on her own at the seaside. Although largely improvised the film has none of the looseness often associated with this approach. Rohmer’s realism is as precise and deceptively simple as ever. There is, however, a touch of magic here.

Credits: Producer, Margaret Menegoz ; director, Eric Rohmer ; writers, Eric Rohmer, Marie Riviere ; photography, Sophie Maintigneux ; music, Jean-Louis Valero ; editor, Maria-Luisa Garcia.
Cast: Marie Riviere, Lisa Heredia, Amira Chemakhi, Vincent Gauthier, Beatrice Romand.

results.title: Pasteur
results.brief_description:
A biopic of the famous doctor whose research culminatd with the discovery of a vaccine against rabbies.

Credits: Director, writer, Sacha Guitry ; photography, Jean Bachelet ; music, Louis Beydts.
Cast: Sacha Guitry, Jean Perier, Henry Bonvallet, Gaston Dubosc, Francois Rodon.

results.title: La Femme En Bleu = the Woman in Blue
results.brief_description:
Pierre, a famous musician, shares his time between his work and Aurelie, his lover. He becomes fascinated by a beautiful stranger, all dressed in blue, he saw only once and uses all his resources and connections to try and find her again.

Credits: Producer, Andre Genoves ; director, Michel Deville ; writers, Michel Deville, Francois Boyer, Leo L. Fuchs ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Bela Bartok, Franz Schubert.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Lea Massari, Michel Aumont, Simone Simon, Genevieve Fontanel.
